data.text:
This weekâ€™s rebroadcast combines two posts from 2005 and 2008 to talk about coming up with a title for your script.

Arguably, the most important part of a film (besides it being good) is the title. Great titles have graced the silver screen, only to have the film bite all kinds of ass. But the title did its job, it got the suckers to watch the flick (i.e. The Phantom Menace). Conversely, a bad title can take the wind out of the sails of a very good film.

My question is, how do you come up with the titles to the films you write? What process do you go through to come up with a title?

â€” Americo

San Francisco, California

The majority of my movies have been adaptations, either of books or existing properties, such as Charlieâ€™s Angels. Obviously, itâ€™s not too hard to pick a title for those ones. (Trivia: the â€œFull Throttleâ€ moniker for the sequel was picked by the marketing team; the working subtitle title was â€œHalo,â€ named for the McGuffin of the story.)

I have been through the name game on several movies.

Go started out as a short film script called â€˜X,â€™ named for the ecstasy Ronnaâ€™s character is trying to deal. When I wrote the full version, my working title was â€™24/7,â€™ but then I saw reviews for a British film called Twentyfourseven, so I nixed that.

About the same time I was writing this script, Iâ€™d made a holding deal with Imagine, for whom Iâ€™d just adapted the kids book How to Eat Fried Worms. As part of the deal, I had to pitch them five projects. One of my ideas was a Die Hard-y thriller about involving a bomber and a TV news crew, which I called â€œGo.â€ Imagine ultimately passed on all of my ideas, but I really liked the title â€œGo,â€ so I just took it for the script I was writing.

It was only after seeing the finished film about four times that I realized how often characters say â€œgoâ€ in the movie â€” and usually at crucial moments. It seems intentional, but trust me, it wasnâ€™t.

One of my never-ending horrors is that an early Columbia press release listed the title as â€œGo!â€ rather than â€œGoâ€, so many reviews and articles about the movie include the exclamation point, thinking thatâ€™s really the title. Itâ€™s not.

I hate that exclamation point with an unmitigated fury. If it somehow became a sentient being, I would kill it without remorse.

Anyway.

Shortly after Go, I was hired to work on an animated movie for Fox called â€œPlanet Ice.â€ That sounds like a sci-fi movie, and it was. The odd thing, I thought, was that there was no icy planet anywhere in the script. The title was a hold-over from many drafts ago. So along with the rewrite, I turned in a list of proposed titles for the movie, most of them centering around the long-lost spaceship at the center of the story.

Two years later, I went to a screening of the nearly-completed movie, which was now called Titan A.E.. â€œTitanâ€ is the name of the missing ship, and the â€œA.E.â€ stands for â€œAfter Earth.â€

A great script with a crappy title faces an uphill battle. Thatâ€™s why I always make sure I have a title I like before I type â€œFADE IN,â€ even if I later change my mind.

So yes, Iâ€™d pay for a great title. An LA Times article about companies that consult on movie titles sounded promising, untilâ€¦

Last summer, Lockhart and Barrie tried to persuade Sony to change the title of â€œHancock,â€ a big-budget action comedy starring Will Smith as an alcoholic superhero known as John Hancock. They told studio executives they thought the current title was vague and pitched alternatives such as â€œHeroes Never Die,â€ â€œUnlikely Heroâ€ and â€œLess Than Hero.â€

Thereâ€™s spit-balling, and then thereâ€™s just spitting. Iâ€™d rather have an inscrutable one-word name than any of those crappy alternatives.

I helped out on that movie as it was transitioning from â€œTonight, He Comesâ€ to â€œTonight He Comesâ€ â€” the removal of the comma helped soften the double-entrendre. But by the wrap party, it was simply Hancock, which serves it well.

At any given point, I have a list of about 30 movies Iâ€™d like to write, and a good 50% of them have titles. Sometimes, thatâ€™s all they really have.

For example, that same thriller I pitched to Imagine is sitting on my to-write list as â€œSouthland.â€ I think thatâ€™s a good title, but I doubt Iâ€™ll ever use it, since (a) Iâ€™ll probably never get around to writing the script, and (b) itâ€™s too much like Richard Kellyâ€™s Southland Tales.

I think some projects sell mostly on their title. A vampire thriller set in Alaska is an okay-not-great idea. But 30 Days of Night is a kick-ass title, which is why Sony bought it. On the flip side, my unsold zombie western has been through at least four titles: Deadfall, Devilâ€™s Canyon, Prey, and Frontier. I donâ€™t love any of them, and neither do readers.

But if you have a good title for it, by all means share.
